intro: Phacelia ciliata var. mexicana, commonly known as Mexican fringed phacelia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family, characterized by its hairy stems and showy blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun, often found in arid or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are narrow and often have fine hairs, while the flowers are clustered in dense, spike-like inflorescences. This species is valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological importance as a nectar source for pollinators.
